General helper functions

{% raw %}

assert_and_print[source]

assert_and_print(s_in, s_expected)

Assert equality of s_in and s_expected and print the result of s_in if the assertion worked

{% endraw %} {% raw %}
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
assert_and_print("select asdf\nfrom table1", "select asdf\nfrom table1")

select asdf
from table1
{% endraw %}

General formatting

Basic formatting for SQL queries. Let's use an example throughout the core module.

This is how an input could look like

{% raw %} 
example_sql = """
create or replace table mytable as -- mytable example
seLecT a.asdf, b.qwer, -- some comment here
c.asdf, -- some comment there
b.asdf2 frOm table1 as a leFt join 
table2 as b -- and here a comment
    on a.asdf = b.asdf  -- join this way
    inner join table3 as c
on a.asdf=c.asdf
whEre a.asdf= 1 -- comment this
anD b.qwer =2 and a.asdf<=1 --comment that
or b.qwer>=5
groUp by a.asdf
"""
print(example_sql)

create or replace table mytable as -- mytable example
seLecT a.asdf, b.qwer, -- some comment here
c.asdf, -- some comment there
b.asdf2 frOm table1 as a leFt join 
table2 as b -- and here a comment
    on a.asdf = b.asdf  -- join this way
    inner join table3 as c
on a.asdf=c.asdf
whEre a.asdf= 1 -- comment this
anD b.qwer =2 and a.asdf<=1 --comment that
or b.qwer>=5
groUp by a.asdf
{% endraw %}

and this is how we would like to format it

{% raw %} 
expected_sql = """CREATE OR REPLACE TABLE mytable AS -- mytable example
SELECT a.asdf,
       b.qwer, -- some comment here
       c.asdf, -- some comment there
       b.asdf2
FROM   table1 AS a
    LEFT JOIN table2 AS b -- and here a comment
        ON a.asdf = b.asdf -- join this way
    INNER JOIN table3 AS c
        ON a.asdf = c.asdf
WHERE  a.asdf = 1 -- comment this
   and b.qwer = 2
   and a.asdf <= 1 --comment that
    or b.qwer >= 5
GROUP BY a.asdf;"""
print(expected_sql)

CREATE OR REPLACE TABLE mytable AS -- mytable example
SELECT a.asdf,
       b.qwer, -- some comment here
       c.asdf, -- some comment there
       b.asdf2
FROM   table1 AS a
    LEFT JOIN table2 AS b -- and here a comment
        ON a.asdf = b.asdf -- join this way
    INNER JOIN table3 AS c
        ON a.asdf = c.asdf
WHERE  a.asdf = 1 -- comment this
   and b.qwer = 2
   and a.asdf <= 1 --comment that
    or b.qwer >= 5
GROUP BY a.asdf;
{% endraw %}

Let's start by defining the main statements. The main statements all also require a new line

{% raw %}
{% endraw %}

We also would like to capitalize the AS operator

{% raw %}
{% endraw %}

We need first to capitalize the main statements

{% raw %}

capitalize_statements[source]

capitalize_statements(s, statements)

Capitalize SQL statements statements in string s

{% endraw %} {% raw %}
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
print(capitalize_statements(example_sql, CAPITAL_STATEMENTS))

CREATE OR REPLACE TABLE mytable AS -- mytable example
SELECT a.asdf, b.qwer, -- some comment here
c.asdf, -- some comment there
b.asdf2 FROM table1 AS a LEFT JOIN 
table2 AS b -- and here a comment
    ON a.asdf = b.asdf  -- join this way
    INNER JOIN table3 AS c
ON a.asdf=c.asdf
WHERE a.asdf= 1 -- comment this
anD b.qwer =2 and a.asdf<=1 --comment that
or b.qwer>=5
GROUP BY a.asdf
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
assert_and_print(
    capitalize_statements(
        "seLecT asdf, qwer FrOM table1", 
        CAPITAL_STATEMENTS
    ), "SELECT asdf, qwer FROM table1"
)

SELECT asdf, qwer FROM table1
{% endraw %}

We need also to remove newlines and multiple spaces because the may be arbitrary

{% raw %}

remove_newlines_mspaces[source]

remove_newlines_mspaces(s)

Remove newline and too many spaces characters. Newline characters in SELECT statement with comments are replaced by special token [EOC] (end of comment) because otherwise we cannot format SELECT statements with comments properly

{% endraw %} {% raw %}
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
print(remove_newlines_mspaces(example_sql))

create or replace table mytable as -- mytable example seLecT a.asdf, b.qwer, -- some comment here[EOC]c.asdf, -- some comment there[EOC]b.asdf2 frOm table1 as a leFt join table2 as b -- and here a comment on a.asdf = b.asdf -- join this way inner join table3 as c on a.asdf=c.asdf whEre a.asdf= 1 -- comment this anD b.qwer =2 and a.asdf<=1 --comment that or b.qwer>=5 groUp by a.asdf
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
assert_and_print(
    remove_newlines_mspaces(
"""
SELECT asdf, qwer,
qwer1,    qwer2
FROM table1
"""
    ), "SELECT asdf, qwer, qwer1, qwer2 FROM table1"
)

SELECT asdf, qwer, qwer1, qwer2 FROM table1
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
assert_and_print(
    remove_newlines_mspaces("""
SELECT asdf, qwer, -- some comment
qwer1,    qwer2
FROM table1
WHERE asdf=1
"""), "SELECT asdf, qwer, -- some comment[EOC]qwer1, qwer2 FROM table1 WHERE asdf=1"
)

SELECT asdf, qwer, -- some comment[EOC]qwer1, qwer2 FROM table1 WHERE asdf=1
{% endraw %}

Next we would like to have each main statement in a separate line

{% raw %}

breakline_statement[source]

breakline_statement(s, statements)

Write a newline in s for all statements

{% endraw %} {% raw %}
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
print(breakline_statement(example_sql, MAIN_STATEMENTS))

create or replace table mytable as -- mytable example
select a.asdf, b.qwer, -- some comment here
c.asdf, -- some comment there
b.asdf2
from table1 as a
left join 
table2 as b -- and here a comment
on a.asdf = b.asdf  -- join this way
inner join table3 as c
on a.asdf=c.asdf
where a.asdf= 1 -- comment this
anD b.qwer =2 and a.asdf<=1 --comment that
or b.qwer>=5
group by a.asdf
{% endraw %}

In combination with removing newlines and multiple spaces

{% raw %} 
print(breakline_statement(remove_newlines_mspaces(example_sql), MAIN_STATEMENTS))

create or replace table mytable as -- mytable example
select a.asdf, b.qwer, -- some comment here[EOC]c.asdf, -- some comment there[EOC]b.asdf2
from table1 as a
left join table2 as b -- and here a comment
on a.asdf = b.asdf -- join this way
inner join table3 as c
on a.asdf=c.asdf
where a.asdf= 1 -- comment this anD b.qwer =2 and a.asdf<=1 --comment that or b.qwer>=5
group by a.asdf
{% endraw %}

Specific formatting and validation

Now we will format each statement individually

SELECT

{% raw %}

format_select[source]

format_select(s)

Format SELECT statement line s

{% endraw %} {% raw %}
{% endraw %}

Simple usage without comments

{% raw %} 
assert_and_print(
    format_select("select aSdf, cast(qweR as numeric),  Asdf,qwer1"),
    "select aSdf,\n       cast(qweR as numeric),\n       Asdf,\n       qwer1"
)

select aSdf,
       cast(qweR as numeric),
       Asdf,
       qwer1
{% endraw %}

More advanced usage with comments in SELECT

{% raw %} 
assert_and_print(
    format_select("select asdf, cast(qwer as numeric), -- some comment[EOC]ASDF, qwer1"),
    "select asdf,\n       cast(qwer as numeric), -- some comment\n       ASDF,\n       qwer1"
)

select asdf,
       cast(qwer as numeric), -- some comment
       ASDF,
       qwer1
{% endraw %}

Correcting common mistake on the flow: comma at end of SELECT

{% raw %} 
assert_and_print(
    format_select("select qwer1,   asdf,"),
    "select qwer1,\n       asdf"
)

Correcting mistake: Comma at the end of SELECT statement
select qwer1,
       asdf
{% endraw %}

FROM

{% raw %}

format_from[source]

format_from(s)

Format FROM statement line s

{% endraw %} {% raw %}
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
assert_and_print(format_from("from table1"), "from   table1")

from   table1
{% endraw %}

(LEFT / RIGHT / INNER / OUTER) JOIN

{% raw %}

format_join[source]

format_join(s)

Format JOIN statement line s

{% endraw %} {% raw %}
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
assert_and_print(format_join("inner join table1"), "    inner join table1")

    inner join table1
{% endraw %}

ON

Helper function

{% raw %}

add_whitespaces_between_symbols[source]

add_whitespaces_between_symbols(s)

Add whitespaces between symbols in line s

{% endraw %} {% raw %}
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
assert_and_print(
    add_whitespaces_between_symbols(
        "WHERE asdf= 1 and qwer=>1 or blabla ='asdf'"
    ), "WHERE asdf = 1 and qwer => 1 or blabla = 'asdf'"
)

WHERE asdf = 1 and qwer => 1 or blabla = 'asdf'
{% endraw %} {% raw %}

format_on[source]

format_on(s)

Format ON statement line s

{% endraw %} {% raw %}
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
assert_and_print(format_on("on a.asdf =b.asdf"), "        on a.asdf = b.asdf")

        on a.asdf = b.asdf
{% endraw %}

WHERE

{% raw %}

format_where[source]

format_where(s)

Format WHERE statement line s

{% endraw %} {% raw %}
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
assert_and_print(
    format_where(
        "WHERE asdf= 1 and qwer=1 or blabla ='asdf'"
    ), "WHERE  asdf = 1\n   and qwer = 1\n    or blabla = 'asdf'"
)

WHERE  asdf = 1
   and qwer = 1
    or blabla = 'asdf'
{% endraw %}

Format all statements

{% raw %}

format_statement_line[source]

format_statement_line(s)

Format statement line s

{% endraw %} {% raw %}
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
print(format_statement_line("select asdf, qwer"))

select asdf,
       qwer
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
print(format_statement_line("left join table1 as abc"))

    left join table1 as abc
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
print(format_statement_line("where asdf=1 and qwer='things' and blabla=0 or stuff=-1"))

where  asdf = 1
   and qwer = 'things'
   and blabla = 0
    or stuff = -1
{% endraw %} {% raw %}

format_statements[source]

format_statements(s)

Format statements lines s

{% endraw %} {% raw %}
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
print(format_statements("select asdf, qwer\nfrom table1"))

select asdf,
       qwer
from   table1
{% endraw %}

Write a ; at the end of query

{% raw %}

add_ending_semicolon[source]

add_ending_semicolon(s)

Add ending semicolon for SQL query s

{% endraw %} {% raw %}
{% endraw %}

Basic usage

{% raw %} 
assert_and_print(
    add_ending_semicolon("select asdf from table1"), 
    "select asdf from table1;"
)

select asdf from table1;
{% endraw %}

Also works with multiple lines

{% raw %} 
assert_and_print(
    add_ending_semicolon("select asdf\nfrom table1\nwhere asdf = 1"), 
    "select asdf\nfrom table1\nwhere asdf = 1;"
)

select asdf
from table1
where asdf = 1;
{% endraw %}

It does not add another semicolon if there is already one there

{% raw %} 
assert_and_print(
    add_ending_semicolon("select asdf\nfrom table1\nwhere asdf = 1;"), 
    "select asdf\nfrom table1\nwhere asdf = 1;"
)

select asdf
from table1
where asdf = 1;
{% endraw %}

Putting everything together

to format a simple query without subqueries

{% raw %}

format_simple_sql[source]

format_simple_sql(s)

Format a simple SQL query without subqueries s

{% endraw %} {% raw %}
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
assert_and_print(
    format_simple_sql(example_sql),
    expected_sql
)

CREATE OR REPLACE TABLE mytable AS -- mytable example
SELECT a.asdf,
       b.qwer, -- some comment here
       c.asdf, -- some comment there
       b.asdf2
FROM   table1 AS a
    LEFT JOIN table2 AS b -- and here a comment
        ON a.asdf = b.asdf -- join this way
    INNER JOIN table3 AS c
        ON a.asdf = c.asdf
WHERE  a.asdf = 1 -- comment this
   and b.qwer = 2
   and a.asdf <= 1 --comment that
    or b.qwer >= 5
GROUP BY a.asdf;
{% endraw %}

Queries with subqueries

This is how we could (badly) write a query with subqueries

{% raw %} 
example_with_subqueries = """
select asdf, cast(qwer as numeric), -- some comment
qwer1
from 
(select asdf, qwer, from table1 where asdf = 1) as a
left 
join (select asdf, qwer2 from table2 where qwer2 = 1) as b
on a.asdf = b.asdf
where qwer1 >= 0
"""
print(example_with_subqueries)

select asdf, cast(qwer as numeric), -- some comment
qwer1
from 
(select asdf, qwer, from table1 where asdf = 1) as a
left 
join (select asdf, qwer2 from table2 where qwer2 = 1) as b
on a.asdf = b.asdf
where qwer1 >= 0
{% endraw %}

and this is the way we would like to have it nicely formatted

{% raw %} 
expected_with_subqueries = """
SELECT asdf,
       cast(qwer AS numeric), -- some comment
       qwer1
FROM   (SELECT asdf,
               qwer
        FROM   table1
        WHERE  asdf = 1) AS a
    LEFT JOIN (SELECT asdf,
                      qwer2
               FROM   table2
               WHERE  qwer2 = 1) AS b
        ON a.asdf = b.asdf
WHERE  qwer1 >= 0;
""".strip()
print(expected_with_subqueries)

SELECT asdf,
       cast(qwer AS numeric), -- some comment
       qwer1
FROM   (SELECT asdf,
               qwer
        FROM   table1
        WHERE  asdf = 1) AS a
    LEFT JOIN (SELECT asdf,
                      qwer2
               FROM   table2
               WHERE  qwer2 = 1) AS b
        ON a.asdf = b.asdf
WHERE  qwer1 >= 0;
{% endraw %}

Helper functions to handle subqueries

{% raw %}

extract_outer_subquery[source]

extract_outer_subquery(s)

Extract outer subquery in query s

{% endraw %} {% raw %}
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
assert (
    extract_outer_subquery(
        "() () (\nSELECT () (\nSELECT ())) ()"
    ) == [6, 30]
)
{% endraw %} {% raw %}

format_subquery[source]

format_subquery(s, previous_s)

Format subquery in line s based on indentation on previous_s

{% endraw %} {% raw %}
{% endraw %}

Main function handling queries with subqueries

{% raw %}

format_sql[source]

format_sql(s)

Format SQL query with subqueries

{% endraw %} {% raw %}
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
assert_and_print(
    format_sql(example_with_subqueries),
    expected_with_subqueries
)

Correcting mistake: Comma at the end of SELECT statement
SELECT asdf,
       cast(qwer AS numeric), -- some comment
       qwer1
FROM   (SELECT asdf,
               qwer
        FROM   table1
        WHERE  asdf = 1) AS a
    LEFT JOIN (SELECT asdf,
                      qwer2
               FROM   table2
               WHERE  qwer2 = 1) AS b
        ON a.asdf = b.asdf
WHERE  qwer1 >= 0;
{% endraw %}

It even works with simple queries without subqueries, therefore generalizing the format_simple_sql() function

{% raw %} 
assert_and_print(
    format_sql(example_sql),
    expected_sql
)

CREATE OR REPLACE TABLE mytable AS -- mytable example
SELECT a.asdf,
       b.qwer, -- some comment here
       c.asdf, -- some comment there
       b.asdf2
FROM   table1 AS a
    LEFT JOIN table2 AS b -- and here a comment
        ON a.asdf = b.asdf -- join this way
    INNER JOIN table3 AS c
        ON a.asdf = c.asdf
WHERE  a.asdf = 1 -- comment this
   and b.qwer = 2
   and a.asdf <= 1 --comment that
    or b.qwer >= 5
GROUP BY a.asdf;
{% endraw %}

Nested subqueries

The function is also robust against nested subqueries

{% raw %} 
example_nested_subqueries = """
select asdf, qwer
from (select a.asdf
    from (select asdf, qwer from table2) as a
        inner join (select asdf, qwer from table3) as b
            on a.qwer = b.qwer
)
"""
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
expected_nested = """SELECT asdf,
       qwer
FROM   (SELECT a.asdf
        FROM   (SELECT asdf,
                       qwer
                FROM   table2) AS a
            INNER JOIN (SELECT asdf,
                               qwer
                        FROM   table3) AS b
                ON a.qwer = b.qwer);"""
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
assert_and_print(
    format_sql(example_nested_subqueries),
    expected_nested
)

SELECT asdf,
       qwer
FROM   (SELECT a.asdf
        FROM   (SELECT asdf,
                       qwer
                FROM   table2) AS a
            INNER JOIN (SELECT asdf,
                               qwer
                        FROM   table3) AS b
                ON a.qwer = b.qwer);
{% endraw %}

More convoluted nested subquery

{% raw %} 
example_convoluted = """
select asdf
from (
    select asdf, qwer
    from (select a.asdf, b.qwer 
          from (select asdf 
                from table1) as a 
            right join (select qwer 
                        from table2) as b
                on a.asdf = b.asdf)
)
"""
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
expected_convoluted = """SELECT asdf
FROM   (SELECT asdf,
               qwer
        FROM   (SELECT a.asdf,
                       b.qwer
                FROM   (SELECT asdf
                        FROM   table1) AS a
                    RIGHT JOIN (SELECT qwer
                                FROM   table2) AS b
                        ON a.asdf = b.asdf));"""
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
assert_and_print(
    format_sql(example_convoluted),
    expected_convoluted
)

SELECT asdf
FROM   (SELECT asdf,
               qwer
        FROM   (SELECT a.asdf,
                       b.qwer
                FROM   (SELECT asdf
                        FROM   table1) AS a
                    RIGHT JOIN (SELECT qwer
                                FROM   table2) AS b
                        ON a.asdf = b.asdf));
{% endraw %}
